PostValue.explanation: This is an episode announcement / podcast link rather than a substantive argumentative post. It may be of mild interest to community members for entertainment, community-building, or incidental ideas, but it isn’t load-bearing for EA or longtermist views and has negligible impact on humanity-level decisions or priorities.

PostRobustness.actionable_feedback:
1) Add a short hook and concrete takeaways — 1–2 sentences summarizing what you and Michael actually argue about (“main claim”), plus 2–3 specific insights or surprising points from the conversation. Right now readers have no reason to click beyond general interest.
2) Say who Michael St. Jules is and why he’s relevant to EA readers — one-line bio (role / relevant work) and one line explaining why this episode matters to the forum (e.g., connects to wellbeing, moral psychology, effective altruism priorities, etc.).
3) Improve discoverability & accessibility — link directly to the episode track/timestamp or embed an audio clip, mention episode length, and include a transcript or show notes (or say where they can be found). Also give a clear contact method for guest inquiries (email or DM) rather than a generic “please reach out.”
PostRobustness.improvement_potential: Actionable, targeted suggestions that fix clear and important omissions: no hook/summary, no guest bio/relevance, poor discoverability/contact info. Implementing them would materially increase listens and credibility without major effort. Not catastrophic mistakes, but without these fixes the post underperforms, so the feedback is critical and well-focused.

PostAuthorAura.explanation: I find no notable record of an author named Elijah Whipple in major EA/rationalist venues (LessWrong, EA Forum, 80,000 Hours, OpenPhil) or in widely known academic/media sources up through my 2024-06 training cutoff. The name does not appear to correspond to any well-known public intellectual or frequent contributor to EA discussion; it may be a pseudonym or a very obscure/early-stage author.

PostClarity.explanation: The post is short, direct, and easy to understand: it announces a podcast episode, states the core question discussed, provides listening links, and invites guests. It lacks background context (who Michael St. Jules is, why the question matters) and a brief summary or key takeaways from the episode, which would make it more informative and compelling.

PostNovelty.explanation: This is primarily a podcast announcement about a common philosophical/psychological question (whether feeling good is the opposite of feeling bad). EA readers will have seen similar discussions about hedonic valence and well‑being many times, so it’s only slightly novel insofar as Michael St. Jules might offer a unique take. For the general public the idea and podcast format are routine and very familiar.

PostInferentialSupport.explanation: The post is an announcement of a podcast episode rather than an argumentative piece: it poses a question but provides no reasoning, claims, or supporting evidence in the text. Strengths: clear, concise invitation and links to the content. Weaknesses: no arguments or empirical evidence presented here to evaluate — to assess the thesis one would need the episode transcript or a summary of the arguments/evidence discussed.

PostExternalValidation.validation_notes: All verifiable empirical claims in the post are accurate. The EA Forum post by Elijah Whipple exists (May 8, 2025) announcing an interview with Michael St. Jules; Apple Podcasts and Spotify podcasters pages show the episode “Is feeling good the opposite of feeling bad? With Michael St. Jules” published May 5, 2025 (≈1h13m). Apple’s show page lists this as the only episode at that time (supporting the claim it was the podcast’s first episode). Michael St. Jules has an EA Forum profile and related posts, which matches the host’s note to check his EA Forum writing. Minor caveat: podcast platform pages sometimes require javascript to render fully and the show received additional episodes after May 2025, so “first episode” is correct as of the posting date (May 2025).
sources: EA Forum post: "Podcast episode with Michael St. Jules" by Elijah Whipple, Effective Altruism Forum — May 8, 2025. https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/posts/C5gvbd8DaFX2GEofL/podcast-episode-with-michael-st-jules

Apple Podcasts: Maybe Better — Episode: "Is feeling good the opposite of feeling bad? With Michael St. Jules" — May 5, 2025. https://podcasts.apple.com/us/podcast/is-feeling-good-the-opposite-of-feeling-bad-with/id1812345244?i=1000706267387

Spotify (Podcasters/creator) episode page: "Is feeling good the opposite of feeling bad? With Michael St. Jules" — Maybe Better (Elijah) — May 05, 2025. https://podcasters.spotify.com/pod/show/elijah523/episodes/Is-feeling-good-the-opposite-of-feeling-bad--With-Michael-St--Jules-e32cn9f
Michael St. Jules EA Forum profile (posts and writings): Effective Altruism Forum user page for Michael St Jules. https://forum.effectivealtruism.org/users/michael-st-jules
Rephonic summary page for "Maybe Better" (shows 1 episode listed, May 5, 2025). https://rephonic.com/podcasts/maybe-better
